images.alt: Alaska Cocktail in a coupe glass with lemon garnish
Making the Alaska Cocktail

ingredients.name: Lemon
ingredients.preparation: Express oils over drink and use as garnish

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled coupe glass
Express oils from lemon peel over the surface and garnish with the peel

notes.history: The Alaska cocktail dates back to the early 20th century and was traditionally made with gin and yellow Chartreuse.
notes.variations: This version is revised with Fino Sherry and Suze for added complexity.
notes.tips: For best results, chill the coupe glass before serving.

images.alt: Vesper cocktail in a martini glass with lemon twist

ingredients.name: Lemon
ingredients.preparation: Express oils over drink and use as garnish

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled martini glass
Garnish with a lemon twist

notes.history: Created by Ian Fleming for his character James Bond in the 1953 novel Casino Royale.
notes.variations: Modern versions sometimes substitute Cocchi Americano for Lillet Blanc, as the latter's formula has changed since the drink was invented.
notes.tips: The original recipe calls for the drink to be shaken, not stirred, but bartenders typically stir this drink to prevent over-dilution.

images.alt: 12 Mile Limit cocktail in a Nick & Nora glass

steps.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass
Express lemon oils over the surface and garnish with the peel

notes.history: Named after the 12-mile boundary from shore that marked international waters during Prohibition, where ships could legally serve alcohol.
notes.variations: Some bartenders add a dash of Angostura bitters or adjust the proportions of spirits.
notes.tips: Use fresh-squeezed lemon juice and homemade grenadine for best results.

images.alt: Sweater Weather cocktail in a coupe glass with cinnamon garnish

ingredients.name: Cinnamon Syrup
substitutions: Simple syrup with a dash of cinnamon

ingredients.name: Maple Syrup
ingredients.preparation: Real maple syrup, not pancake syrup

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled
Double strain into a chilled coupe glass
Express grapefruit oils over the surface
Garnish with freshly grated cinnamon on top

notes.history: A contemporary cocktail designed to evoke the warm, spiced flavors of autumn.
notes.variations: Can be made as a hot toddy variation by using hot water instead of shaking with ice.
notes.tips: The balance of citrus, spice, and sweetness is crucial - adjust to taste.

images.alt: Boulevardier cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice and orange garnish

ingredients.name: Orange
ingredients.preparation: Cut into a wheel or slice

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir until well-chilled (about 30 seconds)
Strain into a lowball glass with a large clear ice cube
Garnish with an orange slice

notes.history: Created in the 1920s at Harry's New York Bar in Paris. Named after a magazine called The Boulevardier.
notes.variations: Can be made with rye whiskey for a spicier profile. Using high-proof bourbon intensifies the flavors.
notes.tips: The quality of the vermouth makes a significant difference. Store opened vermouth in the refrigerator.

images.alt: Mezcal Margarita in a salt-rimmed lowball glass with ice

steps.description: Rim a lowball glass with salt by running a lime wedge around the rim and dipping in salt
Fill the glass with ice cubes
Add all liquid ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled
Strain into the prepared glass
Garnish with a lime wheel (optional)

notes.history: A smoky variation of the classic Margarita, substituting mezcal for tequila to add complexity and depth.
notes.variations: Can be served up in a coupe glass without ice. Some versions add a splash of chili liqueur for heat.
notes.tips: Use a high-quality mezcal that's not too smoky for beginners. The salt rim can be made with half salt, half Tajin for added flavor.

images.alt: The Final Ward cocktail in a coupe glass with cherry garnish

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled
Double strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or coupe glass
Express lemon oils over the surface of the drink
Drop a Luxardo cherry into the drink as garnish

notes.history: Created by Phil Ward at Death & Co. in New York City as a rye whiskey variation of the classic Last Word cocktail.
notes.variations: Can be made with bourbon instead of rye for a slightly sweeter profile. Some bartenders add a dash of Peychaud's bitters.
notes.tips: Use a high-proof rye (like Rittenhouse) to stand up to the strong flavors of Green Chartreuse and Maraschino.

images.alt: Naked & Famous cocktail in a coupe glass

steps.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12-15 seconds)
Double strain into a chilled coupe glass

notes.history: Created in 2011 by Joaquín Simó at Death & Co. in New York. Named after the song by The Strokes and inspired by the equal-parts structure of The Last Word and Paper Plane cocktails.
notes.variations: Some bartenders add a citrus peel garnish. The lime juice can be substituted with lemon juice for a slightly different flavor profile.
notes.tips: The quality of the mezcal is crucial - use one with moderate smoke that won't overpower the other flavors.

images.alt: Old Fashioned cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice, orange slice and cherry

steps.description: Place the sugar cube in a lowball glass and saturate with bitters
Add a small splash of water and muddle until the sugar is nearly dissolved
Add bourbon to the glass
Add a large clear ice cube
Stir gently to chill and slightly dilute
Garnish with orange slice and cocktail cherry

notes.history: One of the oldest known cocktails, dating back to the early 1800s. Originally called the 'Whiskey Cocktail,' it was later referred to as 'Old-Fashioned' to distinguish it from newer variations.
notes.variations: Can be made with rye whiskey for a spicier profile. Some modern versions flame an orange peel over the drink. Wisconsin-style includes muddled fruit and topped with soda water.
notes.tips: Use a large, clear ice cube to slow dilution. The quality of bourbon and bitters makes a significant difference. A luxardo cherry elevates the drink beyond standard cocktail cherries.

images.alt: The Tartan Cocktail in a coupe glass with orange peel garnish

ingredients.name: Drambuie
substitutions: Honey syrup with a dash of Scotch

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled coupe or martini glass
Express orange peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with the orange peel

notes.history: A contemporary cocktail drawing inspiration from Scottish ingredients and flavor profiles. The name 'Tartan' references the traditional Scottish plaid pattern, symbolizing the blend of Scottish elements in the drink.
notes.variations: Some variations use a peated Islay Scotch for more smoke, or add a barspoon of honey syrup for additional sweetness. A lemon peel can substitute for orange.
notes.tips: Use a Highland or Speyside Scotch for balance unless you specifically want the intense peat smoke of an Islay. The sweet vermouth quality significantly impacts the final flavor.

images.alt: 1934 COSMO cocktail in a martini glass with lemon peel and raspberry garnish

steps.description: Add the raspberries to a cocktail shaker (do not muddle)
Add gin, triple sec, simple syrup, and fresh lemon juice to the shaker
Fill shaker with ice and shake vigorously until well-chilled
Double-strain into a chilled martini glass to remove raspberry seeds
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with a skewered raspberry and the lemon peel

notes.history: A historical reinterpretation of the cosmopolitan, based on how the drink might have been made in 1934, with gin instead of vodka and fresh raspberries to add color and flavor rather than cranberry juice.
notes.variations: Can be made with different berries such as blackberries or strawberries for different flavor profiles and colors.
notes.tips: The raspberries provide subtle color and flavor without muddling, allowing the gin to shine through. Double-straining is crucial to remove the raspberry seeds.

images.alt: Neptune's Wrath cocktail in a goblet with flaming Green Chartreuse

ingredients.name: Green Chartreuse
ingredients.preparation: Set on fire as final touch

steps.description: Add lemon juice, simple syrup, absinthe, gin, and egg white to a cocktail shaker without ice
Dry shake vigorously for about 15 seconds to emulsify the egg white
Add ice to the shaker and shake again until well-chilled
Strain into a goblet or sour glass, creating a foamy head
Carefully pour Green Chartreuse over the back of a spoon to float on top of the drink
Using a long match or lighter, carefully ignite the Chartreuse
Serve immediately while the Chartreuse is still flaming

notes.history: A contemporary creation inspired by classic sours with a dramatic presentation element. Named after the Roman god of the sea, the flaming Chartreuse represents Neptune's fiery temper above the frothy 'sea'.
notes.variations: Some variations include a dash of orange bitters or a barspoon of St-Germain elderflower liqueur.
notes.tips: CAUTION: Exercise extreme care when lighting the Chartreuse. The flame should be extinguished or allowed to burn out before drinking. Make sure the glass is heat-resistant. Practice the technique before serving to guests.

images.alt: Paper Plane cocktail in a Nick & Nora glass

steps.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass

notes.history: Created in 2007 by Sam Ross at Milk & Honey in New York. Named after the M.I.A. song 'Paper Planes' which was popular at the time. The recipe follows the equal parts template inspired by the Last Word cocktail.
notes.variations: Some bartenders garnish with a small paper plane. Variations include substituting other amari or using rye instead of bourbon.
notes.tips: Using Amaro Nonino is key to the authentic flavor, though other amari can work in a pinch. The drink should be served very cold.

images.alt: The Last Buzz cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice and salt garnish

ingredients.name: Saline Solution
ingredients.preparation: 20% salt solution (1 part salt to 4 parts water)

steps.description: Add Cynar, Yellow Chartreuse, gin, lemon juice, honey syrup, and saline solution to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass with a large clear ice cube
Sprinkle a small pinch of flake salt on top as garnish

notes.history: A modern variation on the Last Word template that incorporates savory elements through the use of Cynar and salt. The name references both its inspiration cocktail and the artichoke (buzz) component of Cynar.
notes.variations: Can be made with different amari such as Averna or Meletti for different flavor profiles. Some versions add a dash of celery bitters.
notes.tips: The saline solution enhances flavors without making the drink taste salty. Clear ice is recommended for both aesthetics and slower dilution.

images.alt: Amaro Daiquiri cocktail in a frosty coupe glass

ingredients.name: Amaro
ingredients.preparation: Can use two types, 1 oz each

steps.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until very well-chilled
Strain into a frosty, pre-chilled coupe glass

notes.history: A modern twist on the classic Daiquiri that replaces rum with amaro, creating a lower alcohol aperitif-style drink that maintains the refreshing qualities of the original.
notes.variations: Try using two different types of amari, 1 oz. each, for more complex flavors. Popular combinations include Montenegro with Averna or Ramazzotti with Cynar.
notes.tips: Chill the coupe glass well before serving for the best experience. Different amari will create distinctly different cocktails, so experimentation is encouraged.

images.alt: Corpse Reviver #2 cocktail in a coupe glass

ingredients.name: Absinthe
ingredients.preparation: Swirl in glass and discard excess

steps.description: Rinse the coupe glass with absinthe, coating the interior completely, then discard excess
Add gin, Cocchi Americano, Cointreau, and lemon juice to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Strain into the absinthe-rinsed coupe glass

notes.history: Created during the Prohibition era and published in The Savoy Cocktail Book (1930) by Harry Craddock. Part of a family of 'Corpse Reviver' drinks designed as hangover cures. Craddock famously noted, 'Four of these taken in swift succession will unrevive the corpse again.'
notes.variations: Early recipes called for Kina Lillet, which is no longer produced. Cocchi Americano is considered a closer match to the original Kina Lillet than today's Lillet Blanc. Some modern versions add a lemon twist or brandied cherry garnish.
notes.tips: The absinthe rinse is crucial but should be subtle. Too much will overwhelm the other flavors. Equal parts of the four main ingredients create perfect balance.

images.alt: Morning Glory Fizz cocktail in a highball glass with frothy top and orange peel garnish

ingredients.name: Sparkling Water
ingredients.preparation: Added to glass before pouring cocktail

steps.description: Add egg white, Scotch, lemon juice, lime juice, simple syrup, and absinthe to a cocktail shaker without ice
Dry shake vigorously for about 15 seconds to emulsify the egg white
Add ice to the shaker and shake again until well-chilled
Add sparkling water to a highball glass
Strain the cocktail slowly into the glass over the sparkling water
Express orange peel oils over the surface and discard the peel

preparation.method: Dry shake, then wet shake, topped with sparkling water

notes.history: Created in the late 19th century and first published in Harry Johnson's Bartenders Manual in 1882. As its name suggests, it was designed as a morning pick-me-up or hangover cure, combining the soothing qualities of Scotch with revitalizing citrus and fizz.
notes.variations: Some versions use Irish whiskey instead of Scotch. Modern variations might add dashes of bitters or adjust the ratio of lemon to lime juice.
notes.tips: The dry shake is essential for developing the foam. Pour slowly when adding to the sparkling water to maintain the fizz and foam. Non-peated Scotch works best in this application.

images.alt: Twentieth Century cocktail in a coupe glass

steps.description: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Double strain into a chilled coupe glass

notes.history: Created by C.A. Tuck and published in The Café Royal Cocktail Book in 1937. Named after the famous luxury train that ran between New York and Chicago from 1902 until 1967, known as the 'Twentieth Century Limited.'
notes.variations: Some versions add a lemon twist garnish. Original recipes called for Kina Lillet, but Cocchi Americano is considered the closest modern substitute. The cocktail was featured in the 1934 film 'Twentieth Century,' contributing to its popularity.
notes.tips: The unusual combination of chocolate notes from the Crème de Cacao with the herbal qualities of gin and Cocchi Americano works surprisingly well. Use white/clear Crème de Cacao rather than the dark version for a more elegant presentation.

images.alt: Penicillin cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice

steps.description: Muddle fresh ginger slices in the bottom of a cocktail shaker
Add blended Scotch, lemon juice, and honey syrup to the shaker
Fill with ice and shake vigorously until well-chilled
Double strain into a lowball glass over a large clear ice cube
Carefully float the Islay Scotch on top of the drink
Optionally garnish with a piece of candied ginger

notes.history: Created by Sam Ross in 2005 while at Milk & Honey in New York City. The name refers to the drink's honey-ginger combination, which is reminiscent of folk remedies, while the smoky Islay Scotch float serves as the 'medicine.'
notes.variations: Some versions use ginger syrup instead of fresh muddled ginger. A garnish of candied ginger or a lemon peel can be added. The ratio of blended to Islay Scotch can be adjusted for more or less smokiness.
notes.tips: The quality of the Islay Scotch makes a significant difference. Properly floating the Islay Scotch creates layers of flavor as you drink. Fresh ginger is essential for the proper spicy kick.

images.alt: Barnum Was Right cocktail in a coupe glass with lemon peel garnish

ingredients.name: Apricot Brandy
ingredients.preparation: Authentic apricot brandy, not apricot liqueur
substitutions: Rothman & Winter Orchard Apricot Liqueur mixed with a bit of Cognac

ingredients.name: Saline Solution
ingredients.preparation: 20% salt solution (1 part salt to 4 parts water)

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients except the lemon peel to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled coupe glass
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with the lemon peel

notes.history: A Prohibition-era cocktail rediscovered by Ted Haigh (Dr. Cocktail) and included in his book 'Vintage Spirits and Forgotten Cocktails.' The name references P.T. Barnum's famous quote 'There's a sucker born every minute,' suggesting the drink's deceptive approachability despite its potency.
notes.variations: Can be made with dry gin instead of Old Tom for a less sweet profile. The modern addition of saline solution enhances the flavors but wasn't in the original recipe.
notes.tips: The key is finding real apricot brandy (eau-de-vie) rather than artificially flavored liqueur. The saline solution amplifies flavors and balances sweetness without making the drink taste salty.

images.alt: The Town Car cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice and lemon twist

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass with a large clear ice cube
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with the lemon twist

notes.history: A contemporary creation that bridges two classics: the Old Fashioned and the Manhattan. The name 'Town Car' evokes sophistication and elegance, suggesting a drink that brings together traditional elements in a refined way.
notes.variations: Can be made with bourbon instead of rye for a slightly sweeter profile. Some versions increase the proportion of Cognac for more fruit notes.
notes.tips: The quality of the Cognac and vermouth makes a significant difference. The clear ice cube not only looks elegant but also melts slowly to maintain the drink's integrity.

images.alt: Juliet & Romeo cocktail in a coupe glass with mint leaf and rose water garnish

ingredients.name: Cucumber
ingredients.preparation: Muddled with a pinch of salt

ingredients.name: Rose Water
ingredients.preparation: Added on top of mint leaf

steps.description: In a cocktail shaker, muddle cucumber slices with a pinch of salt
Add gin, simple syrup, lime juice, and 3 drops of rose water to the shaker
Fill with ice and shake vigorously until well-chilled
Double strain into a chilled coupe glass
Slap a mint sprig between your palms to release the aroma
Float the mint leaf on top of the cocktail
Place 1 drop of rose water on the mint leaf
Add 3 drops of Angostura bitters around the surface of the drink in a triangle pattern

notes.history: Created by Toby Maloney at The Violet Hour in Chicago. The name plays on Shakespeare's tragic lovers, with the aromatic elements representing the fragrances in the Capulet garden where the famous balcony scene takes place.
notes.variations: Some versions use rosebuds instead of rose water. The exact pattern of Angostura bitters varies by bartender, with some creating more elaborate designs on the surface.
notes.tips: The visual and aromatic presentation is as important as the taste. When adding the bitters, hold the dropper about an inch above the surface to create distinct drops rather than letting them diffuse too quickly. The salt helps to amplify the cucumber flavor.

images.alt: The Rusty Nail cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice and lemon twist

steps.description: Add Scotch and Drambuie to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir gently for about 20 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass with a large clear ice cube
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Optionally, drop the lemon peel into the drink or discard

notes.history: Popularized in the 1950s and became a favorite of the Rat Pack. The origins of the name are disputed, but one story suggests a bartender used a rusty nail to stir the first version of this drink. Another theory is that the rusty color resembles a rusty nail.
notes.variations: The ratio of Scotch to Drambuie can vary widely, from 4:1 in drier versions to 1:1 in sweeter variations. Some versions use a single malt Scotch for more complexity.
notes.tips: Use a quality blended Scotch like Monkey Shoulder that won't overpower the Drambuie. The drink improves as it sits and the ice melts slightly, softening the strong flavors.

images.alt: Sazerac cocktail in a rocks glass with lemon peel

ingredients.name: Absinthe
ingredients.preparation: Swirl in glass and discard excess

steps.description: Chill a rocks glass (traditionally a short, wide old-fashioned glass)
Rinse the chilled glass with absinthe, coating the interior completely, then discard excess
In a mixing glass, combine rye, Cognac, simple syrup, Peychaud's bitters, and Angostura bitters
Add ice and stir until well-chilled (about 30 seconds)
Strain into the absinthe-rinsed glass (traditionally served without ice)
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Traditionally, the lemon peel is discarded rather than used as garnish

notes.history: One of America's oldest cocktails, originating in New Orleans around 1838. Originally made with Cognac, it evolved to use rye whiskey after phylloxera devastated French vineyards in the late 1800s. The modern version often combines both spirits. Named after the Sazerac Coffee House where it was first served.
notes.variations: Traditional versions use only rye or only Cognac. Some modern versions include a small amount of Demerara syrup for richness. The 'improved' Sazerac might include a small amount of maraschino liqueur.
notes.tips: The absinthe rinse is crucial but should be subtle. Using a chilled glass helps the drink stay cold without ice. Peychaud's Bitters are essential and cannot be substituted.

images.alt: Añejo Highball cocktail in a tall glass with ice, orange and lime wedge garnish

steps.description: Fill a highball glass with ice
Add rum, orange curaçao, lime juice, and Angostura bitters to the glass
Top with ginger beer, leaving about 1/2 inch of space at the top
Stir gently to combine ingredients
Garnish with orange and lime wedges

notes.history: Popularized by master bartender Dale DeGroff, this drink is a Caribbean-inspired variation of the classic highball. The name 'Añejo' refers to the aged rum used in the recipe, which adds depth and complexity.
notes.variations: Some versions use a split base of dark rum and aged tequila. A spicier version can be made by muddling fresh ginger in the glass before adding other ingredients.
notes.tips: The quality of the ginger beer makes a big difference - look for one with real ginger and a good spicy kick. A Mexican or Caribbean dark rum adds authentic flavor.

images.alt: Manhattan cocktail in a martini glass with cocktail cherry garnish

ingredients.name: Cocktail Cherry
ingredients.preparation: Luxardo or other high-quality cocktail cherry

steps.description: Add rye whiskey, sweet vermouth, and Angostura bitters to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled martini glass
Garnish with a cocktail cherry

notes.history: Believed to have been created in the 1870s at the Manhattan Club in New York City. Legend says it was invented for a banquet hosted by Lady Randolph Churchill (Winston Churchill's mother), though this story is disputed by historians.
notes.variations: The Perfect Manhattan uses equal parts sweet and dry vermouth. The Rob Roy substitutes Scotch for rye. A Black Manhattan uses amaro in place of vermouth. Some bartenders add a dash of maraschino liqueur.
notes.tips: High-proof rye (100+ proof) like Rittenhouse stands up well to the vermouth. The quality of vermouth makes a significant difference in the final drink. Always refrigerate opened vermouth.

images.alt: Mean Fiddler cocktail in a Nick & Nora glass

ingredients.name: Cinnamon Syrup
substitutions: Simple syrup with a pinch of cinnamon

steps.description: Add all liquid ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir thoroughly until well-chilled (about 30-45 seconds)
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass
Optionally, express orange peel oils over the surface and discard the peel

notes.history: Created by Phil Ward at Death & Co. in New York City. The cocktail combines elements of the classic Tipperary (Irish whiskey, sweet vermouth, and Green Chartreuse) with additional complexity from peated Scotch, Campari, and cinnamon syrup.
notes.variations: Some versions use a different ratio of Campari to Islay Scotch to adjust the bitter/smoky balance. A slightly sweeter variation uses a full barspoon of cinnamon syrup.
notes.tips: The interplay between the herbal Green Chartreuse, smoky Islay Scotch, and bitter Campari creates a remarkably complex flavor profile. The touch of cinnamon syrup helps tie these disparate flavors together. Proper dilution through thorough stirring is crucial.

images.alt: Tuxedo cocktail in a martini glass with citrus twist and cherry garnish

ingredients.name: Absinthe
ingredients.preparation: Swirl in glass and discard excess

ingredients.name: Citrus Peel
ingredients.preparation: Lemon or orange, express oils over drink

steps.description: Rinse a chilled martini or coupe glass with absinthe, coating the interior completely, then discard excess
Rinse a cocktail cherry by briefly dipping in cold water and set aside
Add gin, dry vermouth, maraschino liqueur, and orange bitters to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into the absinthe-rinsed glass
Express citrus peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with the rinsed cherry and citrus twist

notes.history: Named after the Tuxedo Club in New York where it was reportedly created in the late 1800s. There are several variations of the Tuxedo, with this being closest to what's often called the Tuxedo No.2. The Tuxedo is considered a sophisticated enhancement of the classic Martini.
notes.variations: The Tuxedo No.1 uses Old Tom gin and sherry instead of dry vermouth. Some versions omit the absinthe rinse or the maraschino liqueur. In some recipes, a dash of sherry is used in addition to the vermouth.
notes.tips: Rinsing the cherry reduces its sweetness to better complement the cocktail's complex flavors. Plymouth gin provides a softer base than London Dry, allowing the other ingredients to integrate harmoniously.

images.alt: Gibson cocktail in a martini glass with cocktail onion garnish

steps.description: Add gin, dry vermouth, and cocktail onion brine to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled martini or coupe glass
Garnish with cocktail onions on a pick

notes.history: The origin of the Gibson is disputed, with several claimants to its invention in the early 1900s. One popular theory attributes it to illustrator Charles Dana Gibson, who supposedly challenged a bartender to improve the martini. The cocktail onion garnish is what distinguishes it from a standard martini.
notes.variations: The ratio of gin to vermouth varies widely, from 2:1 (as shown here) to much drier versions with just a rinse of vermouth. Some modern interpretations add a dash of orange bitters.
notes.tips: Quality cocktail onions make a significant difference. The touch of brine adds subtle salinity that enhances the gin's botanicals. Plymouth gin works particularly well due to its balanced flavor profile and smooth finish.

metadata.author: Frank Fogarty
metadata.source: Detroit Athletic Club, 1916 (Rediscovered by Murray Stenson)

images.alt: The Last Word cocktail in a coupe glass with cherry garnish

steps.description: Add lime juice, maraschino liqueur, Green Chartreuse, and gin to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora or coupe glass
Drop a cocktail cherry into the drink as garnish

notes.history: Created at the Detroit Athletic Club around 1916 and credited to vaudeville performer Frank Fogarty. The cocktail was largely forgotten during Prohibition and the decades that followed. It was rediscovered in 2004 by Seattle bartender Murray Stenson, who found the recipe in an old cocktail book and added it to the menu at the Zig Zag Café, helping to spark its revival.
notes.variations: The Final Ward (created by Phil Ward) substitutes rye whiskey for gin and lemon juice for lime. The Paper Plane and Naked & Famous are also inspired by the equal-parts formula of The Last Word.
notes.tips: Despite the equal proportions, this cocktail is surprisingly balanced. The herbal intensity of Green Chartreuse is key to the drink's character and cannot be substituted. A perfectly chilled glass helps maintain the ideal drinking temperature.

images.alt: The Bobby Burns cocktail in a coupe glass with lemon twist

ingredients.name: Benedictine
substitutions: Yellow Chartreuse (for a different herbal profile)

steps.description: Add Scotch, sweet vermouth, and Benedictine to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled coupe glass
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with the lemon twist

notes.history: Named after the Scottish poet Robert Burns, this cocktail was created in the 1920s. It's traditionally served on Burns Night (January 25th) to celebrate the poet's birthday. The drink is essentially a Manhattan that substitutes Scotch for rye whiskey and adds Benedictine for herbal complexity.
notes.variations: Some versions add a dash of Peychaud's or Angostura bitters. The original recipe from Harry Craddock's Savoy Cocktail Book (1930) used equal parts Scotch and vermouth with just a dash of Benedictine.
notes.tips: Use a good blended Scotch rather than a heavily peated Islay to avoid overwhelming the other flavors. The sweet vermouth and Benedictine complement the Scotch beautifully, creating a sophisticated, layered cocktail.

images.alt: Vieux Carré cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice and lemon twist

steps.description: Add rye, Cognac, sweet vermouth, Benedictine, Peychaud's bitters, and Angostura bitters to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30-45 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass with a large clear ice cube
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with the lemon peel or discard

notes.history: Created in the 1930s by Walter Bergeron, head bartender at the Hotel Monteleone in New Orleans. The name means 'Old Square' in French and refers to the French Quarter of New Orleans. The cocktail represents the diverse cultural influences of the city, combining American rye whiskey, French Cognac and vermouth, and herbal liqueurs.
notes.variations: Some recipes use different ratios, with equal parts (3/4 oz each) of rye, Cognac, and sweet vermouth being common. A 'Improved Vieux Carré' might include a barspoon of maraschino liqueur.
notes.tips: The combination of two base spirits, vermouth, and a liqueur creates a remarkably complex drink. Proper dilution through thorough stirring is crucial. The quality of the Cognac makes a noticeable difference.

images.alt: Pegu Club cocktail in a coupe glass

steps.description: Add gin, orange curaçao, lime juice, and Angostura bitters to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Double strain into a chilled coupe glass
Optionally garnish with a thin lime wheel

notes.history: Named after the Pegu Club, a British colonial club on the outskirts of Rangoon (now Yangon), Burma, where it was created in the 1920s. The cocktail was the signature drink of the club and became popular among British officers stationed in Burma. It was later featured in Harry Craddock's 'The Savoy Cocktail Book' in 1930.
notes.variations: Some recipes add 1-2 dashes of orange bitters in addition to the Angostura. Modern variations might adjust the sweet-sour balance by reducing the curaçao or lime juice slightly.
notes.tips: The quality of the orange liqueur makes a significant difference. The cocktail should be served very cold. Double straining removes ice shards and lime pulp for a smoother texture.

images.alt: Lumière Cocktail in a coupe glass

steps.description: Add gin, St-Germain, Green Chartreuse, lime juice, and orange bitters to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Double strain into a chilled coupe glass
Optionally garnish with a lime twist

notes.history: Created by Jon Santer at Bourbon & Branch in San Francisco. The name 'Lumière' (French for 'light') refers to the cocktail's bright, fresh character and possibly to its pale green color. It's a modern classic that showcases how complex herbal liqueurs can be balanced with floral and citrus notes.
notes.variations: Some versions adjust the ratios slightly, using equal parts (3/4 oz) of gin, St-Germain, and Green Chartreuse. Others may substitute lemon juice for lime juice or add a small amount of simple syrup for additional sweetness.
notes.tips: The key to this cocktail is balancing the strong herbal character of Green Chartreuse with the delicate floral notes of St-Germain. Fresh lime juice is essential. Serve very cold in a well-chilled glass.

images.alt: Oaxaca Old Fashioned cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice, orange slice, and cocktail cherry

ingredients.name: Cocktail Cherry
ingredients.preparation: Luxardo or other high-quality cocktail cherry

steps.description: Add tequila, mezcal, agave nectar, and Angostura bitters to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass with a large clear ice cube
Garnish with an orange slice and cocktail cherry

notes.history: Created by Phil Ward at Death & Co. in New York in 2007. This cocktail helped popularize mezcal in the United States by introducing it in a familiar, approachable format. Named after the Mexican state of Oaxaca, which is renowned for its mezcal production.
notes.variations: Some versions flame an orange peel over the drink instead of using an orange slice. Others use chocolate bitters in addition to or instead of Angostura. A spicier variation might include a few drops of chile tincture.
notes.tips: The quality of the tequila and mezcal are crucial. Use a good reposado tequila and a not-too-smoky mezcal for balance. The agave nectar should be diluted with water for easier mixing.

images.alt: El Presidente cocktail in a martini glass with orange slice and cherry garnish

ingredients.name: Grenadine
ingredients.preparation: Real pomegranate grenadine, not artificially flavored

ingredients.name: Cocktail Cherry
ingredients.preparation: Luxardo or other high-quality cocktail cherry

steps.description: Add white rum, dry vermouth, orange curaçao, and grenadine to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled martini or coupe glass
Express orange peel oils over the surface of the drink, then discard the peel
Garnish with an orange slice and cocktail cherry

notes.history: Created in Havana, Cuba during Prohibition, likely by American bartender Eddie Woelke who fled to Cuba during the dry era. The cocktail was allegedly named after Cuban President Gerardo Machado, though some sources suggest it was named for an earlier president. It became a symbol of sophisticated Cuban cocktail culture and was very popular in the 1920s and 30s.
notes.variations: Some recipes use equal parts white rum and dry vermouth. Earlier versions may have used more grenadine. A 'Presidente Especial' might substitute honey syrup for the grenadine.
notes.tips: Quality grenadine makes a significant difference - avoid artificially flavored varieties. Some bartenders recommend aged white rum (ron añejo blanco) for more depth. The orange slice and cherry garnish is a traditional Cuban presentation.

images.alt: Boston Sour cocktail in a Nick & Nora glass with frothy top and lemon peel

steps.description: Add bourbon, lemon juice, simple syrup, and egg white to a cocktail shaker without ice
Dry shake vigorously for about 15 seconds to emulsify the egg white
Add ice to the shaker and shake again until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Optionally garnish with the lemon peel or discard

notes.history: The Boston Sour is essentially a Whiskey Sour with the addition of egg white, which creates a silky texture and frothy top. The exact origin is unclear, but it likely emerged in the late 19th century when adding egg white to sours became popular. The 'Boston' designation may reference the city's historical connection to egg-based drinks like flips and nogs.
notes.variations: Some versions add a few dashes of aromatic bitters either to the drink or as a garnish atop the foam. The 'New York Sour' is a variation that adds a red wine float. Some bartenders use a different sweetener such as honey syrup or maple syrup.
notes.tips: The dry shake (without ice) is crucial for properly emulsifying the egg white. Double straining helps remove any egg white chunks. Make sure eggs are fresh and properly stored. For safety concerns, pasteurized egg whites can be used.

images.alt: Black Manhattan cocktail in a coupe glass with cocktail cherry garnish

ingredients.name: Bourbon
substitutions: Rye Whiskey for a spicier profile

ingredients.name: Averna Amaro
substitutions: Other dark amari like Ramazzotti or Cynar 70

ingredients.name: Cocktail Cherry
ingredients.preparation: Luxardo or other high-quality cocktail cherry

steps.description: Add bourbon, Averna amaro, and Angostura bitters to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled coupe or martini glass
Garnish with a cocktail cherry

notes.history: Created by Todd Smith at Bourbon & Branch in San Francisco around 2005. The cocktail is a variation of the classic Manhattan that substitutes amaro for sweet vermouth, resulting in a darker color (hence the name) and a more complex, spiced flavor profile.
notes.variations: Some versions use a mix of amari instead of just Averna. Others split the base between bourbon and rye whiskey. A dash of chocolate bitters is sometimes added for additional complexity.
notes.tips: Use a high-quality bourbon with enough backbone to stand up to the amaro. The cocktail is quite strong, so proper dilution through stirring is important. A high-quality cocktail cherry like Luxardo complements the rich flavors.

images.alt: White Negroni cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice and lemon peel garnish

steps.description: Add gin, Lillet Blanc, and Suze to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass with a large clear ice cube
Express lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with the lemon peel

notes.history: Created in 2001 by British bartender Wayne Collins for Plymouth Gin. The cocktail is a variation of the classic Negroni that uses pale ingredients instead of the traditional red ones, substituting Lillet Blanc for sweet vermouth and Suze (a gentian-based aperitif) for Campari.
notes.variations: Some versions use different ratios, often equal parts (1:1:1) of all ingredients. Other variations might substitute Cocchi Americano for Lillet Blanc or use different gentian liqueurs like Salers or Aveze instead of Suze.
notes.tips: Suze has a distinctive earthy, bitter flavor from gentian root that may be new to many palates. The cocktail is an excellent aperitif to stimulate the appetite before a meal. It can also be built directly in the glass for a more casual preparation.

metadata.author: Harry MacElhone (attributed)
metadata.source: Harry's New York Bar, Paris, circa 1920

images.alt: Sidecar Cocktail in a sugar-rimmed coupe glass

ingredients.name: Simple Syrup
substitutions: Omit if preferring a drier cocktail

steps.description: Prepare the glass by running a lemon wedge around half the rim and dipping it in sugar
Add Cognac, Cointreau, lemon juice, and simple syrup (if using) to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Strain into the prepared sugar-rimmed coupe glass
Optionally garnish with an orange twist, expressing the oils over the surface of the drink

notes.history: Created during Prohibition in the early 1920s, the Sidecar is claimed by both Harry's New York Bar in Paris and the Buck's Club in London. The name allegedly comes from an American army captain who arrived at Harry's Bar in the sidecar of a motorcycle. The cocktail follows the classic sour template and was one of the first to prominently feature Cognac as a base spirit.
notes.variations: The Sidecar is often made following the classic proportions of 2:1:1 (base spirit:orange liqueur:citrus). Some traditionalists omit the simple syrup for a drier cocktail. The 'French School' uses equal parts of all ingredients. A 'Between the Sheets' variation splits the base between Cognac and white rum.
notes.tips: The quality of the Cognac makes a significant difference. V.S.O.P. grade or higher is recommended. The sugar rim is traditional but optional and typically only covers half the glass to allow the drinker to choose between sips with or without sugar.

images.alt: Negroni cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice and orange slice

steps.description: Add gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass with a large clear ice cube
Garnish with an orange slice

notes.history: Created in Florence, Italy around 1919 when Count Camillo Negroni asked bartender Fosco Scarselli at Caffè Casoni to strengthen his favorite cocktail, the Americano, by replacing the soda water with gin. The cocktail was named after the Count and quickly became a classic.
notes.variations: The Boulevardier substitutes bourbon for gin. The Sbagliato uses sparkling wine instead of gin. The White Negroni replaces Campari and sweet vermouth with Suze and Lillet Blanc. Equal parts (1:1:1) is the traditional ratio, though some modern recipes use more gin.
notes.tips: The quality of the vermouth makes a significant difference. Store opened vermouth in the refrigerator. The cocktail can be built directly in the glass for a more casual preparation. A large, clear ice cube not only looks elegant but also melts more slowly, preventing over-dilution.

images.alt: Pisco Sour cocktail in a coupe glass with angostura bitters design on top

ingredients.name: Angostura Bitters
ingredients.preparation: Added on top of the foam as garnish

steps.description: Add pisco, lime juice, simple syrup, and egg white to a cocktail shaker without ice
Dry shake vigorously for about 15 seconds to emulsify the egg white
Add ice to the shaker and shake again until well-chilled
Strain into a chilled coupe glass
Add 3 drops of Angostura bitters on top of the foam
Using a toothpick or cocktail pick, drag through the bitters drops to create a decorative pattern or hearts

notes.history: The Pisco Sour is considered the national drink of Peru (and also claimed by Chile). It was created in the 1920s by American bartender Victor Vaughen Morris at his bar in Lima, Peru. The cocktail was later refined by Mario Bruiget who added egg white and bitters.
notes.variations: Chilean versions typically use Chilean pisco and may omit the egg white. Some modern variations use flavored syrups or infused piscos. In the Maracuyá Sour version, passion fruit puree is added.
notes.tips: The dry shake (without ice) is crucial for properly emulsifying the egg white. Fresh lime juice is essential - key limes (limón sutil in Peru) give the most authentic flavor. The decorative pattern made with bitters on top is a traditional presentation element.

images.alt: Vieux Mot cocktail in a Nick & Nora glass

steps.description: Add gin, lemon juice, St-Germain, and simple syrup to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass
Optionally garnish with a lemon twist

notes.history: The Vieux Mot (French for 'Old Word') is a modern cocktail attributed to bartender Sam Ross. It's a variation on the gin sour that incorporates St-Germain elderflower liqueur. The name may be a play on 'vieux mot,' an old-fashioned French expression, contrasting with the contemporary nature of the drink.
notes.variations: Some versions use less simple syrup and St-Germain for a drier cocktail. Others add a dash of orange bitters. The drink is occasionally served over ice in a rocks glass for a more casual presentation.
notes.tips: The balance between tart lemon juice and the sweetness of St-Germain and simple syrup is crucial. The drink should be quite tart but not unpleasantly sour. Fresh lemon juice is essential for the bright, crisp character of the cocktail.

images.alt: Rabo de Galo cocktail in a lowball glass with ice and citrus peel

ingredients.name: Citrus
ingredients.preparation: Lime or lemon peel, express oils over drink

steps.description: Add cachaça, sweet vermouth, and Cynar to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for about 30 seconds until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass filled with ice
Express lime or lemon peel oils over the surface of the drink
Garnish with the citrus peel

notes.history: Rabo de Galo (literally 'Rooster's Tail' in Portuguese) is a classic Brazilian cocktail originating in São Paulo. The name reportedly comes from a bar where the cocktail was created, which had a neon sign featuring a rooster. Traditionally, it was made with cachaça and red vermouth, but modern versions often include an amaro component.
notes.variations: Some versions use Campari instead of Cynar. Regional variations throughout Brazil may include different amari or bitter liqueurs. The ratio of ingredients can vary, with some recipes calling for equal parts of all ingredients.
notes.tips: Aged (amarela) cachaça works best in this cocktail, providing more complexity than unaged (prata) cachaça. The combination of cachaça's funky sugarcane character with the bitter complexity of Cynar creates a unique flavor profile that's quite different from other similar drinks like the Negroni.

images.alt: Maison Daiquiri cocktail in a coupe glass with optional lime wheel

ingredients.name: Mango Chile Bacardi Rum
substitutions: Bacardi with a dash of mango puree and a pinch of chili

ingredients.name: Saline Solution
ingredients.preparation: 20% salt solution (1 part salt to 4 parts water)

steps.description: Add mango chile rum, lime juice, simple syrup, and saline solution to a cocktail shaker filled with ice
Shake vigorously until well-chilled (about 12 seconds)
Double strain into a chilled coupe glass
Optionally garnish with a lime wheel

notes.history: The Maison Daiquiri is a house special creation that puts a tropical, spicy twist on the classic daiquiri. It incorporates flavored rum and saline solution to enhance flavors, representing modern mixology techniques while respecting the classic daiquiri template.
notes.variations: If Mango Chile Bacardi is unavailable, you can infuse regular white rum with fresh mango and Thai chilies for 24-48 hours. A spicier version can be made by adding a dash of chili tincture. For a less spicy version, regular mango rum can be used.
notes.tips: The saline solution is crucial as it enhances both the sweetness and the heat while balancing the acidity of the lime. Don't skip this ingredient. Fresh lime juice is essential for the bright, tart character of the cocktail. Double straining removes any lime pulp and ice shards for a silky texture.

images.alt: Whiskey Smash cocktail in a lowball glass with ice, lemon wedge and mint sprig garnish

ingredients.name: Mint
ingredients.preparation: Fresh, plus extra sprig for garnish

steps.description: Add mint leaves and quartered lemon to a cocktail shaker
Muddle gently to express oils and juice without shredding the mint
Add bourbon and simple syrup to the shaker
Fill with ice and shake vigorously until well-chilled
Strain into a lowball glass filled with ice cubes
Garnish with a lemon wedge and a slapped mint sprig

notes.history: The Whiskey Smash dates back to at least the 1880s, when it was mentioned in Jerry Thomas' bartending guide. It's essentially a shorter, more rustic version of the Mint Julep, with the addition of muddled lemon. The name 'smash' refers to the muddling technique used to extract flavors from the fresh ingredients.
notes.variations: Some versions add a splash of club soda on top. Different citrus can be used, such as orange or lime. The choice of whiskey can dramatically change the character of the drink - a high-proof bourbon creates a bolder cocktail, while a softer, wheated bourbon produces a more approachable version.
notes.tips: When muddling, press firmly but gently to extract flavors without pulverizing the mint, which can release bitter compounds. The lemon quarters should be muddled with the skin to extract the oils as well as the juice. Use a generous amount of ice when shaking to properly dilute and chill the cocktail.

images.alt: Malibu Bay Breeze cocktail in a lowball glass with tropical fruit garnish

ingredients.name: Tropical Fruit
ingredients.preparation: Pineapple wedge, maraschino cherry, orange slice, etc.

steps.description: Fill a lowball glass with ice
Add Malibu coconut rum
Add pineapple juice
Add cranberry juice
Stir gently to combine
Garnish with tropical fruit pieces

notes.history: The Malibu Bay Breeze is a variation of the classic Cape Codder (vodka and cranberry) and the Bay Breeze (vodka, cranberry, and pineapple), substituting coconut rum for vodka. It became popular in the 1980s and 1990s as Malibu rum gained widespread distribution and tropical-themed cocktails became fashionable.
notes.variations: A Sea Breeze uses grapefruit juice instead of pineapple. For a stronger version, add a float of dark rum on top. Some bartenders layer the ingredients for a gradient effect. A frozen version can be made by blending all ingredients with ice.
notes.tips: Using chilled juices helps maintain the drink's refreshing quality. The sweetness of pineapple juice can vary significantly, so adjust the ratio to taste. While traditionally built in the glass, shaking with ice and straining produces a more integrated flavor.

images.alt: Kentucky Maid cocktail in a lowball glass with ice, cucumber wheel and mint sprig garnish

ingredients.name: Mint
ingredients.preparation: Fresh, plus extra sprig for garnish

steps.description: Add mint leaves and cucumber slices to a cocktail shaker
Muddle gently to express oils and juice without over-muddling
Add bourbon, lime juice, and simple syrup to the shaker
Fill with ice and shake vigorously until well-chilled
Double strain into a lowball glass filled with ice cubes
Garnish with a cucumber wheel speared with a mint sprig

notes.history: Created by Sam Ross at Milk & Honey in New York around 2007. It's part of the 'Maid' family of cocktails, which all feature a base spirit, lime juice, simple syrup, cucumber, and mint. The Kentucky Maid uses bourbon as its base spirit, hence the 'Kentucky' in the name.
notes.variations: Other members of the 'Maid' family include the Gin-Gin Mule (gin), the Old Maid (gin), the Tequila Maid (tequila), the Cino Maid (mezcal), and the Nuevo Maid (tequila and mezcal). A spicier version can be made by adding a thin slice of jalapeño during muddling.
notes.tips: When muddling, press just enough to extract flavors without pulverizing the mint, which can release bitter compounds. Double straining (through both a Hawthorne strainer and fine mesh strainer) helps remove small mint and cucumber particles for a cleaner presentation.

metadata.author: Unknown (Mr. Boston's Official Bartender's Guide)
metadata.source: Mr. Boston's Official Bartender's Guide (1974), modernized by Gary 'Gaz' Regan (1991)

images.alt: Rosita cocktail in a lowball glass with clear ice and lemon garnish

ingredients.name: Lemon
ingredients.preparation: Express oils over drink and use as garnish

steps.description: Add tequila, Campari, sweet vermouth, dry vermouth, and Angostura bitters to a mixing glass filled with ice
Stir for 20-30 seconds until well-chilled and properly diluted
Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube or clear ice block
Express oils from lemon peel over the surface, rub along the rim, and garnish with the peel

notes.history: The Rosita first appeared in the 1974 edition of Mr. Boston's Official Bartender's Guide, creator unknown. It was later rediscovered and modernized by legendary bartender Gary 'Gaz' Regan for his 1991 book The Bartender's Bible, where he increased the tequila proportion and added Angostura bitters. Interestingly, Regan completely forgot he had included it in his book until 2007, when fellow drinks writer Terry Sullivan featured it in an article. After investigating its origins, both discovered that Sullivan had actually found the recipe in Regan's own Bible—a charming case of cocktail amnesia.
notes.variations: Death & Co created 'La Rosita' with refined proportions. Can be served up in a chilled coupe glass instead of on the rocks. Earlier versions used equal parts (1 oz each) of tequila and Campari. Some bartenders prefer orange or grapefruit bitters over Angostura. For a smoky variation, use mezcal. Can be made with Rosa Tequila (tequila aged in wine barrels) for added fruit complexity.
notes.tips: Reposado tequila is preferred over blanco for its oak-aged vanilla and spice notes that complement the Campari. The split vermouth (both sweet and dry) adds complexity and prevents the drink from being too sweet. Use just one dash of bitters—more can overpower the drink. This cocktail can also be built directly in the glass over ice and stirred. Excellent as a pre-dinner aperitif, particularly before Mexican cuisine.

metadata.author: America's Test Kitchen
metadata.source: Cocktails Illustrated: 400+ Recipes for the Home Bartender, from Spirit Forward to Zero Proof

images.alt: Little Baloney cocktail in a coupe glass with cherry garnish

steps.description: Add rye whisky, Cocchi Americano, and Amaro Montenegro to a mixing glass
Fill the mixing glass with ice
Stir for 30-40 seconds until well-chilled and properly diluted
Strain into a chilled coupe glass
Drop in a cherry as garnish

notes.history: The Little Baloney is a modern aperitivo-style cocktail featured in America's Test Kitchen's 'Cocktails Illustrated' (2024). It represents the contemporary trend of combining American whiskey with Italian aperitif wines and amari to create complex, spirit-forward drinks that bridge classic Manhattan territory with lighter aperitivo sensibilities.
notes.variations: This cocktail can be adjusted by varying the amaro - try Cynar for a more savory, earthy profile, or Ramazzotti for deeper baking spice notes. The Cocchi Americano can be replaced with Cocchi Americano Rosa for a slightly more bitter and aromatic version. Some bartenders add 1-2 dashes of orange bitters for additional complexity.
notes.tips: Chill the coupe glass in the freezer beforehand for optimal temperature. The stirring time is crucial - 30-40 seconds provides proper dilution while maintaining the drink's strength. The combination of Cocchi Americano's quinine bitterness and Montenegro's citrus-floral notes creates a beautifully balanced aperitivo that's less sweet than a traditional Manhattan but more approachable than a pure Negroni.
